THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
James L. Williams,       
Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State of South Carolina,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Charleston County
William T. Howell, Circuit Court Judge
Jackson V. Gregory, Post-Conviction 
  Relief Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-007
Submitted January 22, 2004 - Filed March 
  8, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, 
  Chief Capital & Collateral Litigation Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Deputy 
  Attorney General Allen Bullard, Assistant Attorney General Douglas E. Leadbitter, 
  all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Petitioner was convicted of first degree burglary and grand 
  larceny.Â  He was sentenced to thirty years for burglary and ten years for grand 
  larceny, to run consecutively.Â  On direct appeal, this Court affirmed Petitionerâ€™s 
  convictions and sentences.Â  State v. Williams, Op. No. 93-MO-236 (S.C. 
  Sup. Ct. filed August 5, 1993).
Petitionerâ€™s first application for Post-Conviction Relief (PCR) was 
  denied after a hearing.Â Â  No petition for writ of certiorari was filed.Â  After 
  consideration of Petitionerâ€™s second PCR application, Petitioner was granted 
  a belated review of the first PCR order.Â  However, the first PCR transcript 
  was not available, so this Court granted Petitioner a new PCR hearing.Â  A de 
  novo PCR hearing was held, and Petitionerâ€™s application was again denied.Â  
  This petition for writ of certiorari followed.Â  We reverse and remand to the 
  trial court for a new trial.
ISSUE
Was Petitionerâ€™s trial counsel 
  ineffective for failing to object to the trial judgeâ€™s reasonable doubt and 
  circumstantial evidence instructions?
ANALYSIS
Petitioner contends his 
  trial counsel was ineffective for failing to object to the trial judgeâ€™s instructions 
  on reasonable doubt and circumstantial evidence.Â  We agree.
During Petitionerâ€™s trial, the judge instructed the jury on reasonable 
  doubt:

Now by reasonable doubt, I donâ€™t mean a weak or whimsical or imaginary doubt.Â  
  A reasonable doubt is a doubt arising out of the testimony for which a person 
  â€“or lack of testimonyâ€”itâ€™s either arising out of the testimony or lack of testimony, 
  for which a person honestly seeking the truth can give a reason.Â  

The judge also instructed the jury on circumstantial evidence:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

Now to the extent that the State relies on circumstantial evidence it must 
  prove all of the circumstantial evidence beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  They must 
  be wholly and in every particular perfectly consistent with one another.Â  They 
  must point conclusively, that is to a moral certainty, to the guilt of 
  the accused, to the exclusion of every other reasonable hypothesis.Â  That is, 
  they must be absolutely inconsistent with any other reasonable hypothesis than 
  the guilt of the accused.Â  (emphasis supplied)

Trial counsel did not object to either of the charges.Â  The State conceded 
  at the PCR hearing that today, the charges would constitute reversible error.Â  
  However, the State argued that State v. Manning, 305 S.C. 413, 409 S.E.2d 
  372 (1991), which held charges such as these were reversible error, was decided 
  after Petitionerâ€™s trial.Â  The State contends, and the PCR court held, that 
  trial counsel could not be required to anticipate a change in the law, and since 
  Manning was not decided until after Petitionerâ€™s trial, that trial counsel 
  was not ineffective in failing to object to the instructions.Â  E.g. Hill 
  v. State, 350 S.C. 465, 576 S.E.2d 847 (2002).Â  We disagree.Â  
Petitioner must prove that trial counselâ€™s representation fell below 
  reasonable professional norms, and that Petitioner was prejudiced by counselâ€™s 
  failure to object to the charge.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 
  668 (1984), Butler v. State, 286 S.C. 441, 334 S.E.2d 813 (1985).Â  
Petitionerâ€™s trial took place on August 26, 1991.Â  Manning was decided 
  on September 9, 1991.Â  However, Cage v. Louisiana, 498 U.S. 39 (1990), 
  upon which Manning was based, was decided November 13, 1990.Â  In Cage, 
  the United States Supreme Court â€œdisapproved a standard of moral rather than 
  evidentiary certainty in determining an accusedâ€™s guilt or innocence.â€Â  Manning, 
  409 S.E.2d at 416, citing Cage, 498 U.S. at 41.Â  The State argues that 
  although the United States Supreme Court rejected a similar charge in Cage, 
  that there was no way for trial counsel to know that â€œthe South Carolina courts 
  would agree [and] would still require a clairvoyance aspect to analyzing attorney 
  representation.â€ This argument is without merit.Â  Cage was based on the 
  Due Process clause, and applied to all of the states. Trial counsel should have 
  objected to the charge, based on the decision in Cage, which was decided 
  before petitionerâ€™s trial.Â  Trial counselâ€™s representation fell below professional 
  norms.Â  
Petitioner must also prove that he was prejudiced by trial 
  counselâ€™s representation by showing â€œthere is a reasonable likelihood that the 
  jury applied the challenged instruction in a way that violates the Constitution.â€Â  
  Todd v. State, 355 S.C. 396, 309, 585 S.E.2d 305, 308 (2003) quoting 
  State v. Aleksey, 343 S.C. 20, 538 S.E.2d 248 (2000).Â  In this case, 
  the only evidence against Petitioner was circumstantial evidence--fingerprints 
  on the outside of a window of the victimâ€™s house.Â  The jury must have relied 
  on the circumstantial evidence charge, as that is the only evidence that was 
  available to them.Â  Petitioner has proven prejudice.Â  
CONCLUSION
We REVERSE the PCR courtâ€™s decision, and REMAND for 
  a new trial.Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Christina G. deBondt,       
        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Carlton Motorcars, Inc. and Mercedes-Benz,
N.A.,        Petitioners.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO
THE COURT OF APPEALS 

Appeal from Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-008
Heard January 6, 2004 - Filed March 
  15, 2004

RELIEF GRANTED


  
    
      
Hamilton Osborne, Jr., and James Y. Becker, both of Haynsworth 
  Sinkler Boyd, P.A., of Columbia, for petitioners.
Robin B. Stilwell, of Hunter, Tomaszek & Stilwell, of 
  Greenville, for respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal is from an order vacating petitionersâ€™ offer 
  of judgment and placing this case on the trial roster.Â  By unpublished order, 
  the Court of Appeals dismissed petitionersâ€™ appeal because an order setting 
  a case for trial is not directly appealable.Â  We granted petitionersâ€™ request 
  for review.
FACTS
Respondent deBondt is a car collector.Â  In June 1996, she contracted 
  with petitioner Carlton Motorcars, Inc. (Dealership) to purchase the sixteenth 
  1998 Mercedes SLK 230 received by the Dealership from petitioner Mercedes-Benz 
  (Mercedes).Â  As part of the deal, deBondt was entitled to certain promotional 
  materials including CDâ€™s, a keychain, a photo of an SLK prototype, and a â€œfamily 
  albumâ€ of previous Mercedes autos.Â  In October 1997, Dealership delivered an 
  SLK to deBondt for the purchase price of $42,258.60.Â  DeBondt never received 
  the promotional materials.
DeBondt then commenced this action alleging violations 
  of the Dealers Act and the Unfair Trade Practices Act, a cause of action for 
  fraud, deceit, and negligent misrepresentation, and seeking specific performance.Â  
  In October 1998, Mercedes offered to settle the litigation by providing â€œa pristine 
  set of all promotional materials received by charter owners of the SLK 230, 
  complete with personalized letters addressed to Ms. deBondtâ€ and an affidavit 
  confirming the authenticity of the materials.Â  DeBondt ultimately refused the 
  settlement offer claiming the materials were not in the condition promised and 
  the personalized letters contained errors.
Finally, in November 1998, the trial court granted petitioners summary 
  judgment on all causes of action.Â  By decision dated July 24, 2000, the Court 
  of Appeals reversed and remanded for trial.Â  DeBondt v. Carlton Motorcars, 
  Inc., 342 S.C. 254, 536 S.E.2d 399 (Ct. App. 2000).
After the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision, petitioners 
  served on deBondt an offer of judgment for $1,000, plus the promotional materials 
  being held in trust by deBondtâ€™s former attorney and â€œfour disputed letters 
  dated and otherwise revised pursuant to [deBondtâ€™s] written instructions.â€Â  
  This offer of judgment and deBondtâ€™s acceptance was filed with the Clerk of 
  Court on October 30, 2000.Â  
On November 20, 2000, an unrecorded status conference 
  was held.Â  As a result, the trial court issued an order setting the case for 
  trial the following January.Â  
ISSUE

Is the trial courtâ€™s order immediately appealable?Â  
  If not, what is petitionersâ€™ remedy?

DISCUSSION
Petitioners characterize the trial courtâ€™s order as one setting 
  aside a judgment without the proper procedure and claim this order is therefore 
  directly appealable.
Rule 68(a), SCRCP, which provides for an offer of judgment, states that the 
  clerk of court â€œshall enter judgment upon filing of the notice of an 
  offer and acceptance of judgment.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  In this case, judgment 
  was never entered after the offer and acceptance of judgment were filed.Â  Instead, 
  the trial judge set the case for trial.
A judgment is not final until it is written and entered.Â  Ex parte: 
  Reichlyn, 310 S.C. 495, 427 S.E.2d 661 (1993).Â  Because judgment has never 
  been entered, there is no final judgment in this case.Â  Further, the Court of 
  Appeals correctly noted that an order setting a case for trial is not directly 
  appealable.Â  Shields v. Martin Marietta Corp., 303 S.C. 469, 402 S.E.2d 
  482 (1991) (order restoring case to docket is not appealable).
Where an order is not directly appealable, however, this Court may 
  consider the appeal as an application for mandamus where appropriate.Â  See 
  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Scholes, 601 F.2d 1151 (10th 
  Cir. 1979).Â  Mandamus will issue only when there is a specific right to be enforced, 
  a positive duty to be performed, and no other specific remedy.Â  City of Rock 
  Hill v. Thompson, 349 S.C. 197, 563 S.E.2d 101 (2001).Â  It is a coercive 
  writ that orders a public official to perform a mandatory ministerial duty.Â  
  Id.Â  Â Â Â Â 
Here, we find a writ of mandamus appropriate.Â  In pertinent part, our Rule 
  68 tracks the language of Rule 68 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  
  As with the federal rule, the language of our rule is mandatory -- once an offer 
  and acceptance of judgment have been filed, the trial court has no discretion 
  to do anything but enter judgment.Â  Mallory v. Eyrich, 922 F.2d 1273 
  (6th Cir. 1991).Â  Entry of a Rule 68 judgment is simply ministerial.Â  
  Oates v. Oates, 866 F.2d 203 (6th Cir. 1989).Â  
In this case, once the offer and acceptance of 
  judgment were filed, the trial court had no discretion to do anything but order 
  that judgment be entered.Â  Petitionersâ€™ only remedy is a writ of mandamus.Â  
  Accordingly, we order that judgment be entered pursuant to Rule 68.
 RELIEF GRANTED.  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, 
  JJ., concur.
